content: this came up in https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/219381-t-libs/topic/First.20time.20going.20through.20FCP

the libs team has a few docs that indicate that contributors should ping the libs team when they would like us to initiate a stabilization, but it turns out you can't directly use @rust-lang/libs-api if you're not a member of the rust-lang org
https://github.com/rust-lang/triagebot/wiki/Pinging ?
perfect
tyty
that might need an extension to handle pinging normal teams
hmm wait, oh yea
that's about creating new groups to ping
which we do need for a separate issue!
happy to have accidentally helped you!
lol

the libs team was talking about creating ping groups for each platform for tier 2 and tier 3 platforms so we can ping them to review PRs that only touch their stuff, and a larger ping group to notify all the designated maintainers whenever new APIs are introduced that may need platform specific implementations such as available_concurrency
https://github.com/rust-lang/triagebot/blob/master/src/handlers/ping.rs#L28-L35
oof
looks like we'd be going against the grain here too
Do we in practice expect that people would abuse the ability to ping Rust teams?

not sure, but on a related note. Does this just not come up that often? I'm trying to check other team docs but the lang team docs make it seem like only lang team members ever move forward with stabilizations.
I'm not surprised if non-members would hesitate more on lang stabilization than on libs
that makes sense
maybe we should just add an libs-api-fcp-requested issue tag and update the agenda generator for libs-api to add a section for issues waiting on an FCP
and then we can just replace places where it says "ping @rust-lang/libs-api" with "request an fcp with @rustbot modify labels +libs-api-fcp-requested"

The goal for the if is just an abundance of caution; less so for Rust teams than for the ping groups (which are often e.g. experts from companies), and I want to keep their inboxes to high value pings ideally.

It could probably be relaxed.

I think for this particular case, though, pinging feels unfortunate - at least IMO, a team wide ping is often not quite the right thing. Maybe a @rustbot nominate command, which I've discussed a bunch with Niko, would work well

simulacrum said:

I think for this particular case, though, pinging feels unfortunate - at least IMO, a team wide ping is often not quite the right thing. Maybe a @rustbot nominate command, which I've discussed a bunch with Niko, would work well

that's consistent with what I meant by the new issue tag
Long-term, I think it is worth considering relaxing who can start FCPs beyond just the folks on the resulting list - maybe not to the whole world, but at least team members.
we could already have them use I-libs-api-nominated which is a catchall for elevating issues to the attention of the team
I am mildly opposed to a new issue tag; I think a proliferation there is not typically useful, and somewhat harmful.
fair enough, +1 to rustbot nominate command
We don't currently permit nominating from unauthenticated accounts (https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/triagebot.toml#L11), but also for no particular reason.
It would be easy enough to drop that and add a nominate command (maybe taking a team name, or drawing from the T- labels on the issue).
The recently implemented rustbot note might be a good fit too, since it automatically lets us include the reasoning into the issue description.

Josh Triplett said:

Do we in practice expect that people would abuse the ability to ping Rust teams?

I think the answer to that is we don't know until we have actually enabled said ability. If people start abusing it it could just be limited to people who have made at least one commit to one of the repositories. There are apparantly no rules against breaking changes like this :grinning_face_with_smiling_eyes:
